questions.text: Which special stain is commonly used to aid in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease?
questions.explanation:
Rubeanic acid stain

Stains the copper present within cytosolic granules of hepatocytes

Oil red O stain

Stains lipids (Option A)

PAS stain

Stains cells with high glycogen storage and also stains basement membrane (Option B)

Prussian stain

Stains hemosiderin / stored iron (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pancreatic cystic neoplasms is true?

options.label: B
options.text: Mucinous cystic neoplasms (MCNs) occur predominantly in males.

options.label: C
options.text: Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs) have a risk of malignant transformation.

options.label: D
options.text: Mucinous cystic neoplasms typically have a central scar on imaging.

questions.correct_answer: C. Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs) have a risk of malignant transformation.
questions.explanation:
Features

Serous cystadenoma (Option A) 

Mucinous cystic neoplasm

Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm (IPMN) (Option C)

Demographics

Females > males

Females > males (Option B ruled out)

Males = females

Location

Head of pancreas

Body or tail of pancreas

Anywhere in pancreas

Morphology

Microcystic , honeycombing appearance with central scar

Macrocystic, multilocular, no central scar (Option D ruled out)

Dilated ducts with papillary projections

Malignancy risk

Low

High

High (main duct> mixed> branch duct)

Histology

Glycogen rich cuboidal cells

Ovarian like stroma with mucin secreting epithelium

Papillary architecture with mucin secreting epithelium

Serum markers

N/A

CEA and CA 19-9

CEA

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic

Abdominal pain due to mass effect

Weight loss

Recurrent pancreatitis or jaundice

Imaging

Microcystic with central scar and stellate calcification

Thin septation

Unilocular or multilocular

Dilated pancreatic duct or cystic lesion

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most strongly associated with the development of acute pancreatitis in adult males?
Which of the following is not a genetic mutation associated with hereditary pancreatitis?
questions.explanation:
Gene

Features

PRSS1 (trypsinogen 1 gene) (Option B)
  • Most common cause for hereditary pancreatitis.
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • Gain-of-function mutation make trypsin resistant to self-inactivation
  • Increased risk of developing chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic cancer.

SPINK1(Option C)
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance
  • Loss of function mutation encoding a trypsin inhibitor

CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) (Option D)
  • Loss of CFTR leads to abnormal secretions
  • Promote plugging and duct obstruction
  • Associated conditions: recurrent sinopulmonary infections, intestinal obstruction, diabetes, and male infertility.

CASR (Calcium-sensing receptor):
  • Mutation alters calcium concentrations and activates trypsin.

CTRC (Chymotrypsin C):
  • Responsible for protecting pancreas from trypsin-related injury.

CPA1 (Carboxypeptidase A1):
  • Acts as exopeptidase, regulating zymogen activation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the fibrolamellar variant of hepatocellular carcinoma ?

options.label: A
options.text: Not associated with Hepatitis B, C

questions.correct_answer: A. Not associated with Hepatitis B, C
questions.explanation:
Fibrolamellar variant

Classical HCC

Age

Adolescents and young adults

Older adults

Gender

Male=Female

Male>Female

Predisposing condition

None

Hepatitis B and C, Alcohol, NASH, Hemochromatosis

AFP levels

Normal (Option B)

Increased 

Gene mutation

DNAJB1-PRKACA

TERT, Beta-catenin, TP53

Spread

Lymphatic

Hematogenous (Option C)

Prognosis

Good (Option D)

Poor

Serum markers

Neurotensin B

AFP, PIVKA II, Osteopontin, Glycipan 3, HepPar 1

Histology pathology

questions.text: All of the following increases the risk of Hepatocellular carcinoma, except?

M/C hepatic tumour in children

Hepatoblastoma (Option B)

Hepatocellular carcinoma

M/C cancer, which metastasis to the liver

Colon carcinoma

Angiosarcoma

questions.text: Which condition is characterised by extensive dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall?
questions.explanation:
Porcelain gallbladder (Option A)

Hyalinizing cholecystitis (Option D)

Characterized by extensive dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall.

Characterized by complete replacement of the gallbladder wall and mucosa by dense fibrosis, with or without calcification.

Associated with chronic cholecystitis and an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with developing fatty liver disease?
Which of the following is typically observed in liver biopsy findings of acute hepatitis A infection?
questions.explanation:
Acute Hepatitis

Chronic Hepatitis
  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Councilman bodies
  • Spotty necrosis
  • Dropout necrosis and Kupffer cell hyperplasia
  • Absent or mild portal inflammation
  • Interface hepatitis
  • Ground glass hepatocytes
  • Bridging necrosis
  • Lymphoplasmacytic infiltration
  • Extensive portal inflammation

questions.text: What is the most likely autoantibody detected in Type I autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)?
questions.explanation:
Features

Type I AIH

Type II AIH

More common in
  • Young female
  • Children

Auto-antibodies
  • Anti SMA (Anti smooth muscle antibody) (Option B)
  • ANA (Anti-nuclear antibody)
  • Anti-soluble liver antigen
  • Anti LKM- 1 (Hepatitis C) (Option A)
  • Anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) (Option C)
  • Anti LKM- 3 (Hepatitis D)

Histopathology
  • Interface hepatitis with a plasma cell-rich infiltrate.
  • Foci of necrosis, ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes, and regenerative changes such as hepatocyte rosette formation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with abdominal distension and jaundice. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab tests show elevated liver enzymes and decreased albumin levels. Imaging shows nodules <3mm throughout the liver. Which of the following conditions can present with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Causes of micronodular cirrhosis
(Granule size <3mm)

Causes of macronodular cirrhosis
(Granule size >3mm)
  1. Early stage of Alcoholic Liver Disease (ALD)
  2. Indian Childhood Cirrhosis (ICC)
  3. Primary Biliary Cirrhosis (PBC)
  4. Hemochromatosis (Option C)
  5. Hepatic venous outflow obstruction (Budd-Chiari syndrome)
  1. Late stage of alcoholic liver disease (ALD)
  2. Viral hepatitis (Option A)
  3. Wilson disease (Option D)
  4. Drug-induced hepatitis (Option B)
  5. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with chronic jaundice and mild abdominal discomfort. Examination revealed hepatomegaly. Lab tests indicate elevated levels of direct bilirubin. Upon liver biopsy, a pigmented liver is observed. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for these clinical and pathological findings?
questions.explanation:
Type of hyperbilirubinemia

Disorder

Defect

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia 

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1

Complete deficiency of UGT. (Option A)

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2

Partial deficiency of UGT.

Gilbert syndrome

Very mild deficiency of UGT.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Defect in canalicular MRP2 protein. (Option C)

 

Pigmented liver (due to epinephrine metabolite)

Rotor syndrome

Defect in ATPs (decreased biliary excretion)

 

Non-pigmented liver

questions.text: Which zone of the liver lobule is primarily affected by toxins and drug metabolism?
questions.explanation:
Zone

Location

Hepatocyte characteristics

Sensitivity to Injury

Zone 1
(periportal zone)
(Option A)

Around the portal tracts

High oxygenation, reduced metabolic activity,
Rich blood supply

 Least susceptibile to toxin-mediated and ischemic injury

Zone 2
(mid zonal zone)
(Option B)

Between zone 1 and zone 3

Intermediate oxygenation, metabolic activity and blood supply

Moderate susceptibility to toxin-mediated and ischemic injury

Zone 3 (perivenous zone/ pericentral zone)
(Option C)

Around the central vein

Low oxygenation,
active metabolism,
Poor blood supply

Susceptible to drugs/toxin-mediated damage and  ischemic injury during hypoperfusion of the liver

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not typically involved in promoting fibrogenesis and hepatic stellate cell activation in chronic liver diseases?
questions.explanation:
Factors

Role in hepatic pathology

Interleukin 10 (Option C)
  • Antiinflammatory
  • Inhibits hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Reduces fibrogenesis by counteracting pro-inflammatory cytokines

Interleukin 6 (Option A)
  • Pro-inflammatory
  • Stimulates hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Promotes fibrogenesis and inflammation in chronic liver diseases
  • Associated with hepatic regeneration

Platelet derived growth factor (PDGF) (Option B)
  • Stimulates hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Promotes proliferation and migration of HSC to site of injury
  • Contributes to fibrogenesis

Transforming growth factor - β (TGF-β) (Option D)
  • Promotes profibrotic cytokines in liver diseases
  • Stimulates HSC activation and transformation into myofibroblast
  • Enhances Extracellular Matrix production and inhibits ECM degradation
